Dear Ms. Shillings:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager Jessica VandenHeuvel at (616) 204-6992.

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4142 Health Service; Policies and Procedures
Section (1) An institution shall establish and follow written health service
Description policies and procedures addressing all of the following:
(e) Dispensing medication.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation In December 2023 youth did not receive their medication due to
the facility running out of medications.
Investigation Interviews:
Youth B was interviewed via teams on 2/14/2024. Youth B was
at the facility in December. Youth B receives medications at the
facility in the morning and at night. Youth B reported there was
one time he did not get his medication due to being out of one of
his medications. Youth B did not recall which medication. Youth B
reported he went without his medication for a week. Youth B did
not recall when this occurred. Youth B reported he did receive his
medication on 12/25/2023 at the facility.
Youth H was interviewed via teams on 2/14/2024. Youth H was
at the facility in December. Youth H receives medications at the
facility in the morning, afternoon, and at night. Youth H reported
he always receives his medications at the facility.
Youth N was interviewed via teams on 2/14/2024. Youth N was
at the facility in December. Youth N receives 5pm medications
every day. Youth N reported he always receives his medications
at the facility except when his medication runs out and the facility
needs to get more. Youth N reported this happened once
however he did not recall when. Youth N reported he only missed
the medication for one day as the new prescription came the next
day. Youth N reported he got to the facility on December 30th and
received his medication on 12/30/2023 and 12/31/2023.
Youth P was interviewed via teams on 2/14/2024. Youth P was
at the facility in December 2023. Youth P reported he takes
medications at the facility in the morning, afternoon, and evening.
Youth P reported he has always received his medications at the
facility. Youth P does take Metformin however Youth P did not
2

recall if there was a time at the end of December when he was not
receiving his Metformin.
Supervisor 1 was interviewed via teams on 2/14/2024.
Supervisor 1 began working at the facility the end of October as a
supervisor however became a youth specialist in early February.
Supervisor 1 did not have any concerns with youth receiving their
medications in December 2023. There are occasions when the
medications are not in the cart for supervisors to dispense which
occur when a new youth arrives at the facility and only comes with
one week of medications, the youth will be scheduled with the
Psychiatrist however it takes time then for the medications to
arrive at the facility. Another situation where medications are not
available is when youth run out of the medications and have no
refills left, which then typically takes a day for the new prescription
to come. The only other situation is when youth go to the hospital
and the hospital calls a prescription into the wrong pharmacy.
Supervisor 1 did recall some medication not being in the
medication cart in December, specifically for Youth Q, and that it
took some time for his medication to come to the facility however
Supervisor 1 did not recall all the specifics. Supervisor 1 also
recalled something about Youth P’s Metformin however could not
recall specifically what the issue was. Supervisor 1 did not believe
there was an issue with the Pharmacy. Supervisor 1 regularly
passed medications on her shift. Supervisor 1 denied ever
forgetting to pass medications. Supervisor 1 reported she
received an employee discipline for there being blanks on the
MAR. Supervisor 1 reported she is not always the supervisor on
shift passing medications and there were times other supervisors
passed the medications. Supervisor 1 reported she was not
working for all the days that it was alleged she left blanks in the
MAR. Supervisor 1 believed there is an issue with the computer
that is used to document on the electronic MAR, and she has
shared these concerns with Administrator 2.
Supervisor 2 was interviewed via telephone on 2/14/2024.
Supervisor 2 passes medications at the facility. Supervisor 2 had
no concerns with medications in December 2023 that she was
aware of. Health System Coordinator did tell Supervisor 2 she had
reached out to the pharmacy several times regarding medications
that were out at the facility and new medications not being
received. Supervisor 2 reported she was unsure of the specifics
of the situation as Health System Coordinator in responsible for
that part and Supervisor 2 is responsible for passing the
medications to youth that are available in the cart. Supervisor 2
3

recalled an issue with Youth P’s Metformin however did not recall
specifics regarding what the issue was.
Supervisor 3 was interviewed via teams on 2/14/2024.
Supervisor 3 passes medications typically on the afternoon shift
however occasionally works the morning shift. Supervisor 3 did
not have any concerns with youth not receiving medications in
December 2023 or ever. Supervisor 3 reported there are times at
the facility where youth run out of medications before refills arrive
at the facility. At times when new youth arrive, youth come with a
minimum of seven days of medications and the youth see the
Psychiatrist on the next scheduled day the Psychiatrist is
scheduled to provide services at the facility at which time the
Psychiatrist will prescribe medications which typically take a day
to arrive at the facility however sometimes longer depending on
the specific youth and situation. Supervisor 3 reported there has
been times where youth medications are not in the medication
cart. When this occurs, Supervisor 3 leaves a note in the
supervisor log and in the electronic MAR, as well as notifies the
Health System Coordinator by putting the empty medication
package in the Health System Coordinator’s mailbox. The
medications that are not available in the cart are typically for new
youth at the facility. Supervisor 3 reported he worked on
12/25/2023 however he worked the 7am-3pm shift. Supervisor 3
did not recall if there was an issue with Youth P’s Metformin in
December 2023. Supervisor 3 reported there should never be a
blank on the MAR as there should always be some sort of
documentation to say if the youth refused, if the medication was
not available, or if the youth was out of the facility on a home
pass. Typically, there are two supervisors scheduled for the
afternoon shift and supervisors coordinate to determine who is
passing medications.
Administrator 1 was interviewed face-to-face at Clarence
Fischer House on 2/5/2024 and via teams on 2/9/2024.
Administrator 1 reported he was not aware of any medication
issues with Advanced Specialty RX at Wolverine Center.
Wolverine Center has been working with Advanced Specialty RX
has been the pharmacy used for some time. Administrator 1 was
aware there were some medication shortages at the pharmacy but
was not able to recall any specifics. Administrator 1 reported he
has been made aware of missed medications at Wolverine
Center. Administrator 1 was made aware of some medication
shortages and advised Nurse to resolve the issue by contacting
Psychiatrist to try to see about alternative medications.
Psychiatrist was not returning the phone calls. Administrator 1
4

reported the facility completes a ASE/ Facilities Checklist however
it has been found that this is not as thorough and has not been
being completed as it was intended to be. Administrator 1 reported
the manifest form is a form used by Advanced Specialty RX and
the facility does not do anything with the manifest other than
maintain the form. Advanced Specialty RX enters all the
prescriptions into the electronic MAR when the prescription is
received from Psychiatrist. There was an issue where the
medications were being entered into the MAR however the
prescription was not received at the facility resulting in the MAR
showing the youth did not receive the medication for the first one
to two days after being prescribed. Administrator 1 reported this
issue has been rectified as now the facility is able to change the
start date in the MAR to the day the prescription arrives at the
facility. Staff are trained to pass medications at the facility by the
facility trainer as well as the facility provides video trainings.
Advanced Specialty RX came to the facility in August or
September 2023 and provided a training as well as provided
training videos.
Administrator 2 was interviewed via teams meeting on
2/9/2024. Administrator 2 reported there was an issue with Youth
P’s medication in December as Youth P receives all of his
medications in a liquid form and the medications arrived and one
of the bottles was broken. Administrator 2 did not recall the
specific as to which medication this was. Advanced Specialty RX
was contacted regarding the issue and sent out the medication to
replace the broken bottle. When youth get low on medications
Health System Coordinator does weekly medication counts and
will notify the Psychiatrist via team notes which youth need refills.
If a youth runs out of a medication the shift supervisor notifies
administration team on the team chat the facility uses and Health
System Coordinator will replenish the medication in the cart.
Administrator 2 reported the facility completes a ASE/ Facilities
Checklist however did not know if this was completed for
December. Administrator 2 reported when youth come to the
facility it is required the youth comes with a minimum of seven
days of medications which allows time for the youth to see the
Psychiatrist at the next scheduled appointment after their arrival.
Psychiatrists meet with youth on Wednesdays. Psychiatrist will
meet with the youth and then prescribe medications which the
Psychiatrist sends to Advanced Specialty RX. Administrator 2 did
not know what process Psychiatrist uses to send the prescriptions
to Advanced Specialty RX. Medications arrive to the facility from
Advanced Specialty RX via FedEx in one to two days. If a
medication does not arrive, Health System Coordinator follows up
5

with Advanced Specialty RX to see if the prescription was not sent
over by the Psychiatrist or why it was not received. Administrator 2
reported she did not know if the shipping manifest from Advanced
Specialty RX is being filled out by the facility. Medications are put
into the medication cart by Health System Coordinator if she is
working when the medications arrive at the facility or if it is outside
Health System Coordinators hours of work, the supervisor opens
the medications and places the medications in Health System
Coordinators mailbox. Staff use “medication not available” on the
MAR when the medication is not available to the staff to provide to
the youth. Administrator 2 reported upon her reviewing the MAR
for all youth in December, the majority of the “medications not
available” appear to be due to the medication passer not being
able to locate the medication in the cart as there were several
where the medication was given before and after the date where it
was marked as “medication not available”. Administrator 2
reported there should never be blanks on the MAR. Administrator
2 reported Health System Coordinator is now sending her weekly
medication counts to her as a result of this special investigation.
Administrator 2 had previously been getting the weekly medication
counts however this process stopped for about one month and
now it is implemented again.
Nurse was interviewed face-to-face at Clarence Fischer
House on 2/5/2024. Nurse is in contact with LPN at Wolverine
Center who handles the medications at the facility. LPN
addresses medications at Wolverine Center however is in regular
communication with Nurse if there is medication not coming into
the facility from the pharmacy or is medications are missed by
staff. Nurse reported she was not made aware of any pharmacy
issues with medications by LPN. Nurse was aware of some issues
in December where the Psychiatrist was not refilling medications
and sending the prescriptions to the pharmacy and the
Psychiatrist was not returning phone calls.
Health System Coordinator was interviewed via teams on
2/9/2024. Health Systems Coordinator is responsible for
scheduling youth medical appointments, taking youth to
appointments, monitoring medications, and providing updates to
the Psychiatrist when youth are getting low on medications for the
Psychiatrist to provide the pharmacy with a new prescription. The
only issue Health System Coordinator is aware of that occurred
with medications in December 2023 was Youth P’s liquid
medication bottle arrived broken at the facility from the pharmacy
and it contaminated Youth C and Youth J’s medications. Health
System Coordinator contacted the pharmacy immediately about
6

the issue and the pharmacy resent Youth P, Youth C, and Youth
J’s medications. The medications arrived the next afternoon. The
only impact this had was Youth J did not get his morning antibiotic
medication. Youth P also came to the facility from home and when
he arrived at the facility, he had an empty bottle of Sertraline and
due to Youth P just arriving at the facility, the facility had Youth P
meet with the Psychiatrist who then prescribed the medication and
signatures needed to be obtained from Youth P’s parent as it is a
psychotropic medication. Once that occurred, Youth P began the
medication. Health System Coordinator reported no other
medication issues in December. Health System Coordinator
denied youth at the facility did not receive their medications in
December due to Advanced Specialty RX not delivering the
medication. The facility has been working with Advanced
Specialty RX for over a year. Advanced Specialty RX medications
arrive within a day and a half of the prescription being sent to the
pharmacy. Health System Coordinator reported she did not recall
ever reaching out to Nurse in December 2023 and reporting
concerns with youth medications not being sent to the facility by
Advanced Specialty RX. In the MAR if there is a blank it usually
means the staff passing medications had a situation happen
requiring them to step away from passing medications and
forgetting where they left out documenting in the electronic MAR.
Medication not available is used in the MAR when a medication
has not yet arrived at the facility. Health System Coordinator
reported there is a refill drawer of medications and sometimes
staff forget to check the refill drawer if a medication runs out.
Health System Coordinator does complete weekly medication
counts to see if new prescriptions are needed by the Psychiatrist.
Health System Coordinator does not cross reference the
medication count with the MAR to ensure the medication matches
what should be left per the MAR.
Complainant was interviewed via telephone on 2/1/2024.
Complainant did not have any specific youth who were impacted
by the allegations. Complainant did not have any other concerns.

Analysis The facility is found in noncompliance. There are several youth
and dates where the MAR was left blank, and it is unknown if the
youth were provided their medications. There appears to be an
internal issue of staff locating the medications in the cart as there
are several youth on several days that indicate medication is not
available however the medication per the MAR was given on days
and times in-between when it is documented the medication is not
available. There is an issue with the facility running out of youth
medication which appears to be an internal issue with refills not
being requested in a timely manner prior to youth running out of
medication. There also appears to be an issue with the facility
requesting refills from the Psychiatrist and receiving the refills
timely. It is unclear if the facility is waiting until the medication is
out to request refills or is not preparing for refills in an adequate
timeframe to allow the Psychiatrist to refill the medication and the
pharmacy to ship the medication.
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE:
It is recommended the facility update their internal policy and
procedure to include a policy for administering medications while
youth are off grounds, clear direction for staff on coding
medication notes to include how it should be documented for
home passes as the facility codes differently using home pass and
medication given to family. It is recommended the facility
addresses youth being removed from the MAR on the date of
discharge or having a way for staff to code this accurately as there
were several youth who had been discharged and medications are
coded as not available when the youth is no longer in the facility.
It is also recommended the facility only document medications
being given in the MAR and not in the Youth Care Worker
Supervisor Logbook. It is recommended the facility create an
internal procedure of proactively requesting medication refills in a
timely manner to allow for the medications to arrive prior to youth
running out of medications. Additionally, it is recommended the
12

agency have a way to clearly and consistently document when
there are medication issues, this could be via incident report.
Conclusion Violation Established
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4142 Health Service; Policies and Procedures
Section (1) An institution shall establish and follow written health service
Description policies and procedures addressing all of the following:
(f) Definition and training of personnel authorized to dispense
medications.
Violation Additional Findings of Non-Compliance
Type
Allegation The agency is not following their written policy regarding staff
training for dispensing medications.
Investigation Interviews:
Supervisor 1 was interviewed via teams on 2/14/2024.
Supervisor 1 received medication training which consisted of an
online video and a quick MAR training which was training on how
to use the electronic MAR system. Supervisor 1 received the
training in mid-November and began passing medications
immediately after completing the training.
Supervisor 2 was interviewed via telephone on 2/14/2024.
Supervisor 2 received medication training within the last year
however could not recall when. Supervisor 2 did not recall how
often medication training is given however reported she attends
whenever it is required as she must have the training to continue
passing medications.
Supervisor 3 was interviewed via teams on 2/14/2024.
Supervisor 3 received medication training approximately one year
ago. Medication training is an hour long and consists of a video,
quiz, and sometimes observation of medication passing.
Medication training is typically once a year. Supervisor 3 has
received medication a few times while he has been employed at
the facility.
Documents Reviewed:
• Wolverine Human Services (WHS) Medication Control
Administration Policy and Site Protocols Policy: The
following titles are authorized for medication administration
duties only after successful completion of the Medication
Administration training curriculum, testing, and
demonstration: Residential Care Supervisors, Licensed
Practical Nurse, Registered Nurse, Medical Assistant,
Health Coordinator, Certified Nurse Assistant, Program
Manager/ Supervisor. Retraining of the Medication
13

Administration training curriculum, testing, and
demonstration will be scheduled quarterly. Managerial
training forms will be completed to show trained curriculum,
testing, and demonstration for authorized titles, with original
at Human Resources and copies with Health Services.
• Supervisor 1’s personnel file: Supervisor 1 received
medication training on 11/14/2023 as Supervisor 1 started
11/6/2023. Supervisor 1 is no longer a supervisor at the
facility and will no longer be passing medications.
• Supervisor 2’s personnel file: Supervisor 2 received
medication training on 1/24/2023 and 6/14/2023.
Supervisor 2 has not received quarterly medication training.
• Supervisor 3’s personnel file: Supervisor 3 received
medication training on 2/22/2022, 6/14/2022, 1/24/2023,
and 9/15/2023. Supervisor 3 has not received quarterly
medication training.
Analysis The facility is found in noncompliance with following the facilities
internal policy for medication training as the facilities policy
indicates quarterly trainings which have not been occurring for
Supervisor 2 and Supervisor 3.
Conclusion Violation Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the current license status be continued.
